Potential initial temporal safety release.

Looking at the output from systemd-analyze, 150 seconds was spent on
tty-related systemd tasks. The default is 256 ttys.

This commit adds a kernel command line parameter to reduce the number
of "legacy" ttys to 32, which reduces boot time by about 90 seconds. I
don't know if we even need 32, so maybe it could be reduced further.

column6: Fix MIT security monitor mis-configuration that did not clear enclave…

column5:
Background: Tags are stored in a two-level hierarchy to exploit
non-uniform distribution of tags and reduce DRAM traffic, with the top
level being a summary tag bit for a "group" of capabilities. On reset,
just this top level is zeroed, with the leaves lazily zeroed.

Bug: When a capability with the tag bit set was first stored to a given
group, thereby flipping the top-level bit from 0 to 1, a numeric error
led to only half of the leaf bits for the group being zeroed, meaning
reading a capability from the upper half of the group would see the
tag as whatever was already in DRAM. This error was introduced when
adding support for 128-bit capabilities with a 64-bit bus, as used by
CHERI on RV64, likely due to confusion about what the 8 on the line in
question meant (it's a bits to bytes conversion, nothing to do with the
capability size in bytes).

Fix: Change the 16 back to an 8.

Fixed by: @jrtc27
column6: CHERI: Fix a tag cache bug that resulted in spurious tags.

When run as a non-root user, pam_enclave.so was segfaulting because it
tried to open a log file for output in /root and it was not checking
for errors.

Also, /dev/security_monitor was not accessible by non-root users.

This removes the debug log, which is not needed, from pam_enclave.so
to avoid the first problem.

The install-enclaves.sh script is updated to chmod
/dev/security_monitor so it is accessible to all users.

by the use of CHERI C.

* Researcher reported that they ran out of space unpacking a tar file
 * debian.img was created with genext2fs, which seems to be sparing in the number of inodes it allocates
 * Made new filesystem by using mkfs -t ext4 and copied in contents of previous debian.img
 * Now now more than 60% of inodes are free:

[nix-shell:~/SSITH-FETT-Target/SSITH-FETT-Binaries/MIT/osImages/connectal]$ df -ik root/
Filesystem     Inodes IUsed IFree IUse% Mounted on
/dev/loop0      48864 16954 31910   35% /home/centos/SSITH-FETT-Target/SSITH-FETT-Binaries/MIT/osImages/connectal/root

[nix-shell:~/SSITH-FETT-Target/SSITH-FETT-Binaries/MIT/osImages/connectal]$ df -k root
Filesystem     1K-blocks   Used Available Use% Mounted on
/dev/loop0        752568 321228    376656  47% /home/centos/SSITH-FETT-Target/SSITH-FETT-Binaries/MIT/osImages/connectal/root

Fixes #20

I have updated ssith-aws-fpga with reboot support and we would like to provide it to researchers. Moreover, I have also updated the XDMA driver to include some bug fixes landed upstream by Xilinx within the past 24h, one of which could result in the DMA engine being given an illegal operation (specifically being asked to process a list of descriptors that crosses a page boundary) that manifests as an I/O error to the host software; whilst I have never seen this occur in normal operation, as soon as I started trying to reboot (which means another large DMA burst to load ELF files) I'd hit it almost immediately, and I imagine it's possible to hit even without the strenuous act of rebooting and re-loading ELF files, if unlikely. Please rebuild the software for the CentOS AMI in a clean environment (the drivers' Makefiles don't capture all the dependencies and so report being up-to-date even when some files have changed), as even without the reboot issue I don't want to be running drivers that are known to have bugs.

The `kfcgi` binary was dynamically linked against zlib. Looking [build script](https://github.com/DARPA-SSITH-Demonstrators/SSITH-FETT-Voting/blob/dc1304af455db4cb39d6bfaf45adf79e455216fb/source/builddeps.sh#L101) in the voting repo, it seems like the intent was to use static linking, although the `pkg-config` line did not actually add the right flags for me. This PR replaces the `kfcgi` binaries with ones that are linked correctly, fixing the CI failure in DARPA-SSITH-Demonstrators/SSITH-FETT-Target#421.

column5: This PR replaces the current FreeBSD application binaries with ones built using clang (DARPA-SSITH-Demonstrators/SSITH-FETT-Target#308). The NGINX binary should also be linked correctly now (DARPA-SSITH-Demonstrators/SSITH-FETT-Target#244).
Add voting app binaries

This PR adds the unmodified application binaries we currently have, along with some incomplete documentation describing the directory structure. Some things I need to think about before merging:
- I went with the second approach from DARPA-SSITH-Demonstrators/BESSPIN-CloudGFE#62, with a directory at the top level for each source of binaries. I can change this if people think that a different structure is better.
- I'm not sure if it makes sense putting our own OS images in this repo, as they are already part of our Nix environment, which makes it very easy to make changes. The FETT tool could have a configurable option to search for images in the Nix environment if they are not present here.
- Images and bitfiles should have some naming scheme which should be documented in the README. I think we would be fine using the conventions we currently have (processor type + GFE target for bitfiles, OS + device for images).
